3 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Two administrators at Boulder Creek High School in the Anthem suburb north of Phoenix have been suspended for 10 days without pay for their participation in a skit recorded on video portraying President Donald Trump and his counselor, Kellyanne Conway.
Principal Lauren Sheahan and Athletic Director Jay Kopas performed a nearly 7-minute skit Jan. 19 for a faculty meeting in which they talked about school news but in a manner some complained was offensive and belittling.
The "parody" was posted to YouTube, but the original video has since been removed.
It "includes references to parents as 'morons,' students as 'weak, loser, stupid, lightweights and zeroes,' and other statements about staff members, the Governing Board, Chinese individuals, people with physical disabilities, and school safety efforts," according to Deer Valley Unified School District records of the letters of suspension issued to Sheahan and Kopas Wednesday.
Additionally, the district superintendent will not recommend Sheahan's contract to be renewed for the next school year.
Kopas may be transferred for the rest of the school year, and his possible contract renewal will rely on his ability to follow policy and repair relationships with students, staff, parents and the community, according to the records.
More on the video and the suspensions The pair worked with a student and instructor to record the skit, which was emailed to all staff Jan. 20. Students, parents and community members began sharing the video online, furious about its content.
News of the incident spread locally and nationally, resulting in hundreds of calls and emails to the school, district and its governing board, some against the skit and some in support, according to the letters.
MORE: Officials at Boulder Creek High School under fire for Trump skit video
The district was initially unaware that Sheahan and Kopas created, performed and recorded the skit, which was "meant to be light-hearted and entertaining and not disparaging," and placed them on paid administrative leave shortly after, according to a statement.
The skit violated numerous district policies, according to the suspension letters written by Dan Courson, DVUSDâ€™s director of administrative leadership and services. Both violated:
Staff ethics policy dictating that employees "maintain standards of exemplary conduct" including "refrains from using school contacts and privileges to promote partisan politics." Staff conduct policy that no employee shall "engage in the use of profane or abusive language, symbols, or conduct." Computer guidelines on using district technology to keep or transmit inappropriate video. Sheahan and Kopas have both been directed to "rebuild relationships with BCHS parents, students, staff and community" through talking and meeting with student groups, staff, parents and the community.
